Wilsonville, OR does not have a policy as such, but the park reservation department works closely with the public works department that maintains the parks and before reservations for special events are approved, they must be cleared by public works to ensure adequate time between events.  As events vary in their impact on the park, the time between may vary, but certainly no sooner than 24 hours.   We have for instance cut our park shelter reservations to once per day, as multiple uses could not be serviced between rentals.   The same general approach is taken for special events.   Events are charged a nominal fee for the set up and break down days for large events, and these dates are secured on the calendar, thus helping to avoid doubling up events for the park.

answers.text:
The City of Portland Parks and Recreation Bureau currently only places limitations on frequency of events in its major public event park, Tom McCall Waterfront Park.  These limitations are placed to provide enough time to allow restoration of the sand based grass turf, as well as to make other incidental repairs while at the same time allowing the public leisure access to their major downtown park.
We do place smaller time restrictions on other specific locations. Our two most notable outdoor wedding facilities; the Shakespeare and Gold Medal wedding gardens are booked in two hour increments with a two hour public access period required in between each booking. At the same time, we only book one of the two gardens at a time. This allows the large number of people who visit the park daily access to one of the gardens at all times. 
Other than these examples there are no overarching guidelines that might give direction when permitting events in the majority of our parks.

answers.text:
Response from Marc Heirshberg, CPRP
Director
Mesa Parks, Recreation and Commercial Facilities
We don’t have a specific policy addressing this – however, our best practice is to space them accordingly so that turf and other natural conditions can recover from the wear and tear of special events ( this will vary based on season, weather, current conditions, etc.) this also allows for other activities too occur at the park, so the general public doesn’t feel as if “their space” is constantly being used for special events.

Bay City, MI hosts many special events in two of its major parks beginning early June through mid September.  We permit events back to back.  Our major events (i.e. River Roar, Fireworks, Pig Gig) obtains exclusive use of the parks, which means they control access to the park and adjacent riverwalk during their multiple day event.  The City has occasionally received complaints about the lack of public access to the park during the summer months, but the community is a strong supporter of these events.  The City does have Special Events Policies and Procedures, which are available on its website baycitymi.org

author: Kevin Safine
text: Does anyone have a policy regarding a required length of time between holding special events within the same City park? For example, if a group holds a special event in your park this weekend, how soon can another large event take place in the same park? We are wondering if any general policies or even "rules-of-thumb" are routinely practiced out there and if those policies could be shared. Thank you.
title: Special Events in Parks
